title: Challenge the Champs conducted by Phillip Alder
excerpt: Bidding challenge where readers compete against champion pairs.

The concept of suprersound openings was costly to Roth and Stone on other hands . . . [They] paid for their solid openings in a different way when they overreached to double uphill games on Deal 3 and 106. In both cases a passed hand jumped to two notrump over a third-hand opening, and both times the originalhand opening and both times the original hand pushed on to a thin game, down one. Six IMPs lost.

Down one; down one. Six IMPs lost. Down on 13 points or better. The Italians opened one notrump and arrived briskly at three notrump, making five. Four spades was down two. A rather silly result, but neither American did anything terrific. Crawfords hand is too-heavy for a one notrump opening (Avarelli-Belladonna play theirs as 17-20 points), I would respond one heart with Becker's hand, but one spade is surely reasonable. Crawford's rebid is a problem—perhaps a two-heart raise or one spade under-bid or a three-spade over-bid of big a three-spade overcall would be better, but two clubs looks all right. 2NT Pass 3 NT (All Pass)

Surly, if two clubs had not been doubled. Rapee would have bid two spades, with the expectation of making it. (Actually, an overtrick is available.)

I don't think he should take such a dim view of his prospects because of the double. And, if he was afraid of a disaster, he tended in American disaster. He psyched repeatedly and was never punished, first? I imagine he intended the two dia- monds as a cue-bid for the majors, but think that Silodor was right to play it to be a suit, at least until the bid got doubled — be a suit, at least until the bid got dou- bled. (These Italian partners frequently bid short diamond suits, for their one- club opening is artificial, and their one- diamond opening is often a three-card suit.)

he opened with three clubs. This re- sulted, it may be recalled, in a five club sacrifice, down 700, when five dia- monds might well have been made.

I charged Rapee with a substantial loss, but I have sympathy for his bid. What article: A few of their errors were shameful—e.g., on Deal 69 they played the hand in a cue bid, on this auction:

Berger Former Cardpool Siniscalco Pass

Potinet led the diamond three! Sinis-calco returned the club king, and Por-quot ruffed. There was no way for Roth to avoid another club loser, and this defense was necessary, too. At the other table D'Alelio was in five hearts (on his own steam, not pushed there), Stochet led the ace of diamonds (they'd signaled for attitude on that ace), then shifted to a spade. D'Alelio pulled trump, stripped out the spades and dia-monds, then end-played West in clubs.

... And there was Forquet's incredible auction on Deal 58. He held:
♠ 8 6 ♥ Q J 4 ♦ A J T 7 ♣ J T 9 4
With both sides vulnerable. Siniscalco opened with one spade, Forquet responded one notrump. Siniscalco re-bid two spades, Forquet tried two notrump, and then end-played West in clubs.

**The Bridge World**

Nilslund could hardly open after tak-ing his partner to task two deals earlier. Following the 14-16 notrump, Staymar and reply; three diamonds was minor-suit Stayman, implying slam interest. Magnus; two diamonds was a relay; and three clubs announced both minors, 4-7 points; two clubs announced both majors; two notrumps was a relay; and 4-5 hearts showed four or five dia-monds and at most three clubs. Pallenmas monds and at most three clubs. Pal-lennius left five clubs was a void or sin-gleton. whereas Nilslund thought it had to be a void, by a passed hand. The Danes had a routine Acol auction, Moron Moron could l risk three no-trump opposite unknown clubs, BvVS auction: The same as that pro-duced by the Land Madison Brothers. Agree: Three spades asked about that suit; the reply showed either no spade control or no aces. Four of clubs asked there; the answer showed either three aces or a void in clubs with no aces. But for Lars' forgetfulness on Deal Six, three spades — four spades — five clubs — six diamonds — pass. Awards: 6 ◊ 10; 5 ◊ 7 6 ◊; 7 ◊ 6 ◊ 1.

**Final score: Pallennias-Nilslund 75, Lars-Moller 69.**

The Swedes squeaked out a close win, but for Lars' forgetfulness on Deal Six, the Danes might have won. That would have deprived the Swedes of their touch qualifying point. Next month's deals are on pages 5 and 12.
